spanishExample: ¡Hola! ¿Me *do you remember?* Fui *president* una vez.
englishTranslation: Hi! Do you remember me? I was president once.

spanishExample: *¡Look at* esa cosa! No la *I saw before.*
englishTranslation: Look at that thing! I didn’t see it before.

spanishExample: ¡Ya está! *At least* hasta *next week.*
englishTranslation: It’s done! At least until next week.
vocabIncluded: ya está: idiom meaning "it's done", "all done", etc.

spanishExample: ¿Cuánto *you want* hacer?
englishTranslation: How much do you want to do?
vocabIncluded: cuánto: adverb meaning "how much?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¿Por qué estaría *angry* por eso?
englishTranslation: Why would I be angry because of that?
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "I would be" (Estar, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Quién es ese hombre por la *street?*
englishTranslation: Who is that man by the street?

spanishExample: El chico y yo estamos por la casa.
englishTranslation: The boy and I are around the house.

spanishExample: El *book* iba a ser por un *Argentinian author.*
englishTranslation: The book was going to be by an Argentinian author.
vocabIncluded: iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ella estaba *sad* cuando él estaba con ella.
englishTranslation: She was sad when he was with her.

spanishExample: Ella estaría aquí si yo no estuviera, pero estoy.
englishTranslation: She would be here If I weren’t present, but I am.
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella va a ir cuando nosotros vayamos.
englishTranslation: She is going to go when we go.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ellas tienen que *know* todo lo que está en *the exam.*
englishTranslation: They(f) have to know everything that is on the exam.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Esas cosas no son buenas.
englishTranslation: Those things aren’t good.

spanishExample: Estábamos por ahí, pero no teníamos *money.*
englishTranslation: We were around, but we didn’t have money.

spanishExample: Están por hacer dos cosas sí o sí.
englishTranslation: They are about to do two things either way.
vocabIncluded: the use of "por" after Estar to mean "about to"

spanishExample: Estaría *happy* si yo también fuera su amiga.
englishTranslation: She’d be happy if I also were her friend(f).
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Este es tu día.
englishTranslation: This is your day.

spanishExample: Estuve *sad* porque fueron *mean* conmigo.
englishTranslation: I got sad because they were mean with me.

spanishExample: Fue a *the pharmacy* por mí.
englishTranslation: She went to the pharmacy on my behalf.

spanishExample: Fuimos a un lugar que tenía *tables* de más.
englishTranslation: We went to a place that had extra tables.

spanishExample: Fuimos amigos ese año y las *we saw* ahí.
englishTranslation: We were friends(m) that year and we saw them(f) there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: Ha sido lo que yo soy ahora.
englishTranslation: She has been what I am now.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Habrá *a problem* y lo tendremos que *solve.*
englishTranslation: There will be a problem and we’ll have to solve it.
vocabIncluded: habrá: "there will be" indicating existence (Haber, future, impersonal)
tendremos: "will have", "we will have" (Tener, future, 1st person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Has estado *playing* en vez de *working.*
englishTranslation: You have been playing instead of working.
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Hay que *stay indoors* en *the summer.*
englishTranslation: There is a need to stay indoors in the summer.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: *I called* a la chica que era mi mejor amiga.
englishTranslation: I called the girl who was my best friend.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: *I hope* que nunca estés aquí.
englishTranslation: I hope you are never here.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I hope* que siempre tengas todo lo que *you want.*
englishTranslation: I hope you always have everything you want.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I hope* que vaya de *the store* a su casa.
englishTranslation: I hope she goes from the store to her house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Íbamos a ir porque tenía de todo.
englishTranslation: We were going to go because it had a bit of everything.
vocabIncluded: tiene de todo: "has some of everything" (idiom)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Iban a ser *doctors,* pero no lo son.
englishTranslation: They were going to be doctors, but they aren’t.
vocabIncluded: iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
lo: "that way", "like that", constructed like a direct object (esp with Ser and Estar)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: La vida es así para él.
englishTranslation: Life is that way for him.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"

spanishExample: Lo tienen todo ahí en su casa.
englishTranslation: They have it all there at their house.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
lo + Tener + todo: "to have it all" (idiom)

spanishExample: Mi amigo *wants* que yo tenga *a grill.*
englishTranslation: My friend(m) wants me to have a grill.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Mi *mom would get mad* si fuera con mis amigos.
englishTranslation: My mom would get mad if I went with my friends.

spanishExample: No está de más *to study this material.*
englishTranslation: It couldn’t hurt to study this material.
vocabIncluded: no está de más: "it couldn't hurt" (idiom)

spanishExample: No fue *a coincidence.*
englishTranslation: It wasn’t a coincidence.

spanishExample: No hay ni *food* ni *money.*
englishTranslation: There isn’t either food or money.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: No lo tengo todo cuando no estás por ahí.
englishTranslation: I don’t have it all when you’re not around.
vocabIncluded: lo + Tener + todo: "to have it all" (idiom)

spanishExample: No tengo todo lo que *you requested* para nada.
englishTranslation: I don’t have everything that you requested at all.

spanishExample: Sería bueno si tuviera muchos *books.*
englishTranslation: It would be good if he had a lot of books.
vocabIncluded: sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si esta casa estuviera en Perú, ella estaría ahí con ellos.
englishTranslation: If this house were in Peru, she would be there with them.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si fuera conmigo, estaría en el lugar.
englishTranslation: If she went with me, she would be at the place.
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si fuera *rich,* tendría una casa en *the beach.*
englishTranslation: If I were rich, I would have a house on the beach.
vocabIncluded: tendría: "would have", "I would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Sí o sí, usted le va a *give* todo.
englishTranslation: No matter what, you(formal) are going to give her everything.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Si tuviera tiempo, lo *I would watch* todo.
englishTranslation: If I had time, I would watch it all.

spanishExample: Si *we said* eso, estaríamos siendo *rude.*
englishTranslation: If we said that, we would be being rude.
vocabIncluded: estaríamos: "would be", "we would be" (Estar, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Todos estamos *happy* contigo, hasta la chica.
englishTranslation: We’re all happy with you, even the girl.

spanishExample: Tú sí fuiste el *winner.*
englishTranslation: You WERE the winner(m).
vocabIncluded: sí: adverb meaning "indeed" or otherwise providing positive emphasis

spanishExample: Váyanse, estaremos aquí otra noche.
englishTranslation: (All of you) Leave, we will be here another night.
vocabIncluded: estaremos: "will be", "we will be" (Estar, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Ve y *buy* uno.
englishTranslation: Go and buy one.
